nodes.text: Conservation of money in transactions and statistical mechanics principles imply characteristic statistical equilibria of monetary distributions and provide a useful physical-science perspective on monetary economics

If money is locally conserved in pairwise transactions among many agents and transaction rules satisfy time-reversal symmetry or are additive, the stationary distribution of money P(m) is exponential (Boltzmann-Gibbs)

When transaction rules are multiplicative (percentage transfers) or break time-reversal symmetry, money distributions deviate from pure exponential and can become Gamma-like with exponential tail or develop a two-class structure with a power-law upper tail

Debt (allowing negative net worth) removes the lower boundary condition that stabilizes money distributions, making debt growth an irreversible diffusive-like process that destabilizes equilibrium unless explicit constraints or enforcement are imposed

Boltzmann kinetic equation and its small-step limit Fokker-Planck (Kolmogorov forward) equation describe evolution of money distribution P(m,t) with drift and diffusion coefficients A = -mean(delta)/dt and B = mean(delta^2)/(2 dt)

Maximum entropy principle and kinetic detailed-balance arguments predict exponential distribution as the maximal-entropy stationary state for conserved additive money dynamics; entropy increases monotonically under the kinetic dynamics

Empirical income data show a two-class distribution: bulk of population follows an exponential distribution while the high-income tail follows a Pareto power law; the fraction of income in the tail spikes during market bubbles and post-crisis liquidity injections

Analysis of IRS data 1983-2013 and Gini comparisons (Fig.1) support the exponential lower class, power-law upper tail, and temporal spikes in upper-class share associated with the dot-com bubble, housing bubble, and Quantitative Easing

Money is a digital accounting token whose functionality to prevent free riding requires that ordinary agents cannot create or destroy it unilaterally; conservation is an accounting constraint inside the private-agent system while the state can inject money across the system boundary
Peer-to-peer lending creates matched money and debt pairs that conserve total money but introduce debt obligations; interest payments require other agents' money and do not create net money

Unconstrained debt accumulation causes widening positive and negative net-worth distributions, entropy growth without saturation, and eventual systemic crises (Minsky moments) unless limits, enforcement, or write-offs occur

Bank lending aggregates and anonymizes debtor-creditor links and effectively creates deposits (liabilities) and loans (assets) simultaneously; this is best described as endogenous debt creation rather than creation of base money

Central bank 'vertical' money creation (monetization, e.g., buying government bonds or toxic assets) injects exogenous money into the private-agent system, which can convert previously endogenous bank-created debt into base money and tends to benefit financial-sector holders, increasing inequality
Boundary conditions (e.g., nonnegative money balances or caps on debt) are essential to reach stationary monetary distributions; without such boundaries the system does not equilibrate

Conclusion: A physics-style treatment emphasizing conservation, kinetic equations, entropy, and explicit boundary conditions explains emergence of inequality, the instability introduced by unconstrained debt and banking, and shows that state monetary injections are the ultimate source of net monetary profit for the capitalist system
